title: Task Attribute Distance for Few-Shot Learning: Theoretical Analysis and Applications
abstract: arXiv:2403.03535v1 Announce Type: cross  Abstract: Few-shot learning (FSL) aims to learn novel tasks with very few labeled samples by leveraging experience from \emph{related} training tasks. In this paper, we try to understand FSL by delving into two key questions: (1) How to quantify the relationship between \emph{training} and \emph{novel} tasks? (2) How does the relationship affect the \emph{adaptation difficulty} on novel tasks for different models? To answer the two questions, we introduce Task Attribute Distance (TAD) built upon attributes as a metric to quantify the task relatedness. Unlike many existing metrics, TAD is model-agnostic, making it applicable to different FSL models. Then, we utilize TAD metric to establish a theoretical connection between task relatedness and task adaptation difficulty. tldr: 本文介绍了基于任务属性距离（TAD）的度量方法，用于量化训练和新任务之间的关系，以及该关系对不同模型在新任务上适应困难的影响。
